node.title: Interpolate from CSV
node.bodyText:
Is there a way to interpolate values stored in a CSV file onto a mesh? e.g. I have a CSV containing xyz coordinates and corresponding values of various parameters at those locations, and I would like to use these to set the values of AuxKernels on my mesh.
Cheers,
Heather
Hi @hsheldon , long time no see.... are your values stored at a grid.  If so, PiecewiseMultilinear might be helpful?  https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseMultilinear.html

Hi Andy,
It's a structured grid but the z-spacing varies. So I don't think PiecewiseMultilinear helps unfortunately. Although I suppose I could perhaps interpolate it onto a regularly spaced grid.

Hello
As long as it is a structured grid you can work directly with PiecewiseMultiLinear. See this folder
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/test/tests/functions/piecewise_multilinear
for examples. twoD1.txt has irregular spacing in X and Y
The AXIS Z parameter wont have regular spacing but this is ok
Guillaume

Thanks Guillaume,
The z spacing varies in x and y so that won't work unfortunately. I think I will have to resample onto a regular grid.

ah ok. Does it vary often? If it only varies like 2 or 3 times you could define 3 different functions then take the sum
I also have a PR up for general CSV interpolation (nearest neighbor), you could use that. No guarantees on when it ll be merged.
#19118
If you do want that, let me know I ll fix the merge conflicts
It varies everywhere, it's not predictable at all. Anyway, I wrote a script to interpolate to a regular grid, then PiecewiseMultilinear worked perfectly - very happy with the result.

node.title: Solve did not converge after a specific time step
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am new to MOOSE and trying to apply it for study about thermal pressurization.
I am trying to study a 2D-quarter of borehole model with DirichletBC of Parsed function which should work with previous version.
However, convergence issue happens after a specific time step of around t = 0.013 with the update version. The error is listed below.

I guess the converge fails when the material changes its state to plastic.
Are there any way to solve this error to visualize the change of temperature, porepressure and mechanical dissipation in the plastic state?
This is the input file I am using. Thank you very much.
Best regards,
Kowin Tang
@vev001 is the right person to ask about redback questions.

Thanks @hugary1995 . We’ll take it from here with @pou036 .
@kingmantang, we have a number of solver options and preconditioning in redback, depending on the problem. We’ll have a look at your input file and come back to you for the best solution.

these residuals are exactly 1e-10? This seems weird. Anything in petsc hard coded to output such a residual

Possibly not. We do not really hard code anything anywhere in PETSc. It seems to me that the residual is corresponding to some constant of equations when considering that the time step is super small.  The time step is so small that the right hand side of the linear system is zero, and then the direction is zero.  Noway to make any progress on the nonlinear level when the direction is zero.
You might look into physics before you hit this step time. Check whether or not the physics still looks correct before you reach this time step.

We typically use these options in Redback to indeed tackle the stiff transition to plasticity when the full THMC system is solved (yes, it involves some convincing and often we hardcode PETSc haha). In this case there might be better solver options, the problem is not that stiff. I will check tomorrow and provide a suggested solution. Bear with me

node.title: unit and num processors
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone!
How  can I change the units of mesh in my model?  Such as, unit of mesh in the project Case2DegradEigenBFI3_4um.i is micron.
When I compile the file, I find that num processors is always 1. How can I change this to improve my computing speed.
Parallelism:
Num Processors:          1
Num Threads:             1
Thanks

Hello
if the mesh is in micron, then you will have to make sure every material property and so on is in micron. There are utilities to help you do this from the input file. I ll post a link later.
Which module are you trying to use? Some have much better support for different unit systems than others.
To change the number of processors you have to use MPI.
run mpirun -n XX app-opt -i input_file.i
where app is you app, XX is the number of processors you want to use.
Guillaume

here are two pages about units in moose
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/utils/Units.html
and in the input file:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/input_syntax.html
Thanks for  your help.

node.title: Virtual element
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am a newbie here. Over the past two weeks, I have been going through the tutorials and workshops and have been fascinated with this framework and the materials available for learning.
I have a general question. I am doing research on subsurface flow problems and occasionally dealing with systems with nonconvex meshes. If I am not mistaken, FEM is not the best method for general polygonal elements such as might be found in reservoir simulation. I was wondering if there is any plan in future to incorporate Virtual Element (VEM) in Moose.
Thank you :-)

AFAIK MOOSE doesn't support Ansatz shape functions and polygonal elements yet. I think you'll have to start from libMesh if you want to develop it yourself, but I'm afraid that many low level operations assume convex elements.
Thank you for the clarification. Is there any plan/interest for the implementation of VEM in the near future (in a year or so?)?
I don't know to be honest. Perhaps you should unmark this as the answer, and others can see and comment on your question.
Ping @roystgnr

There's been some interest in adding support for more general polygonal elements (well, hexagons, but if we were to do the work anyway I'd hope to handle general N) to libMesh, but just using macroelement subdivision of convex polygons, not a fancy new weak form, and even for the macroelement implementation I'm not sure if there's any funding/time for it in the next year or two.
The first Google hit I find for "Virtual Element Method" is someone in the UK who likes the blue Beamer LaTeX theme and the cross benchmark problem for Cahn-Hilliard, so I can already tell we could have been best friends in another life, but I'm afraid that here and now this is the first I've heard of VEM.

Oh, and to be clear, this probably is a good answer:

AFAIK MOOSE doesn't support Ansatz shape functions and polygonal elements yet. I think you'll have to start from libMesh if you want to develop it yourself

Correct and correct.

but I'm afraid that many low level operations assume convex elements

I think this is only correct for some particular physics implementations (contact in Moose?) not for anything at the libMesh level ... however libMesh does assume that it makes sense to talk about function definitions in "master" space cleanly distinct from the transformation between that space and "physical" space, and we can get some ugly code (see the Clough-Tocher shape functions for example) in cases where that's not the most sensible description.

node.title: No module named 'hit'
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am trying to install MOOSE on my Macbook with M1 following the steps https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html.
For Mambaforge3, i installed MacOSX-arm64.
When I was trying to do the last step (Compile and test), I got the following error:
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'hit'
Thank you for your message! As this is a question regarding conda installation, I am moving this to the Discussions forum. You might get some email notifications about this.

To get started in troubleshooting your issue, could you load up your moose conda environment and post the output of the command conda list? This is just to confirm that everything we expect to have installed is there.
EDIT: To summarize the thread below, conda was unable to install the moose packages due to a conda channel that did not exist. Removing the channel allowed proper syncing of the package metadata, which allowed download of the moose packages. See below for more details.

It seems that the issue is with the packages. There is no packages installed in mambaforge3/envs/moose
When I tried to reinstall the packages using mamba install moose-tools moose-libmesh, I got the following:
RuntimeError: Multi-download failed
public/osx-arm64                                              No change
pkgs/r/osx-arm64                                   279.0 B @ 286.0 B/s 404 failed  0.1s
conda/moose/osx-arm64                              199.0 B @ 203.0 B/s 404 failed  1.0s
conda/moose/noarch                                 195.0 B @ 199.0 B/s 404 failed  1.0s

Given that these are 404 errors, it appears as though there's an issue either with your internet connection/firewall or the configuration of the conda channels. Could you show the output of the following command?
conda config --show channels

I run the command on the base env. The o/p is:
channels:

https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
https://mooseframework.org/conda/moose
conda-forge
defaults

For comparison, the channel configuration for a newly configured M1 Mac Mini is as follows:
% conda config --show channels
% channels:
    - https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
    - conda-forge

the presence of conda/moose in your output is odd to me, as I only see public or conda-forge in the channel sync and download process output.

The second channel you have listed does not exist, which explains the 404 errors. Please remove it by performing the following command:
conda config --remove channels https://mooseframework.org/conda/moose

And then try installing the packages again in the activated moose environment.

It seemed to be working fine so far. I am running a test right now. I will let you now if I got any issues.
Thank you so much.

node.title: February 2022 News
node.bodyText:
The February 2022 MOOSE Newsletter has been released!
A content summary is below:

Legacy Input Parameter Removal (Effective 1 March 2022)
MOOSE Improvements

Thermal Hydraulics Module is now open source
New Lagrangian solid mechanics kernels now available in the tensor mechanics module
Automatic differentiation support in MOOSE functions
Brayton cycle model demonstrated using the Thermal Hydraulics Module
Finite volume Navier Stokes incompressible and weakly compressible implementations reworked to handle face interpolations of velocity


MOOSE Bug Fixes and Minor Enhancements

node.title: Field Split Preconditioner or Physics Based Preconditioner
node.bodyText:
I'm doing a comparison against another FE package, and getting some wickedly quick runtimes from it, I think its down to the way it solves one field and then another, rather than solving both. What I can solve in 12 hours, it can solve in 2, for the exact same physics setup. Both use PETSc, so I'm currently assuming its down to the pre-conditioing. It has some interesting PC settings which I've ported across;
[Preconditioning]
  [FSP]
    type = FSP
    topsplit = 'temp_disp'
    [temp_disp]
      splitting = 'temp disp'
      splitting_type = additive
    []
    [temp]
      vars = 'temp'
      petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type -ksp_rtol
                             -pc_hypre_boomeramg_strong_threshold -pc_hypre_boomeramg_coarsen_type 
                             -pc_hypre_boomeramg_interp_type -ksp_type
                             -pc_hypre_boomeramg_agg_nl -pc_hypre_boomeramg_agg_num_paths'
      petsc_options_value = ' hypre      boomeramg   1.0e-8            
                              0.75       HMIS                       
                              ext+i cg
                              4  2'

    []
    [disp]
      vars = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
      petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_type -ksp_rtol 
                             -pc_gamg_type -pc_gamg_agg_nsmooths
                             -pc_gamg_threshold  -pc_gamg_coarse_eq_limit
                             -pc_gamg_square_graph -pc_gamg_reuse_interpolation
                             -mg_levels_esteig_ksp_type -mg_levels_ksp_type
                             -mg_levels_pc_type -mg_levels_ksp_chebyshev_esteig_steps
                             -mg_levels_esteig_ksp_max_it
                             -pc_gamg_sym_graph'
      petsc_options_value = ' gamg     cg         1e-12 
                              agg     1     
                              0.015   1000
                              2       1
                              cg     chebyshev
                              jacobi   20
                              20
                              true'
    []
  []
[]

This is my first attempt, but I get the following error
[0]PETSC ERROR: --------------------- Error Message --------------------------------------------------------------
[0]PETSC ERROR: No support for this operation for this object type
[0]PETSC ERROR: DM type moose does not implement DMCreateGlobalVector
[0]PETSC ERROR: See https://www.mcs.anl.gov/petsc/documentation/faq.html for trouble shooting.
[0]PETSC ERROR: Petsc Release Version 3.15.1, unknown 
[0]PETSC ERROR: /home/dc-davi4/rds/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose//modules/combined/combined-opt on a  named cpu-p-60 by dc-davi4 Thu Feb 10 13:29:05 2022
[0]PETSC ERROR: Configure options --download-hypre=1 --with-shared-libraries=1 --with-debugging=no --download-fblaslapack=1 --download-metis=1 --download-ptscotch=1 --download-parmetis=1 --download-superlu_dist=1 --download-mumps=1 --download-strumpack=1 --download-scalapack=1 --download-slepc=1 --with-mpi=1 --with-openmp=1 --with-cxx-dialect=C++11 --with-fortran-bindings=0 --with-sowing=0 --with-64-bit-indices --prefix=/home/dc-davi4/rds/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/petsc --with-make-np=24 --prefix=/home/dc-davi4/rds/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/petsc
[0]PETSC ERROR: #1 DMCreateGlobalVector() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/dm/interface/dm.c:961
[0]PETSC ERROR: #2 DMGetGlobalVector() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/dm/interface/dmget.c:165
[0]PETSC ERROR: #3 KSPCreateVecs() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/ksp/interface/iterativ.c:1564
[0]PETSC ERROR: #4 PCSetUp_MG() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/pc/impls/mg/mg.c:1179
[0]PETSC ERROR: #5 PCSetUp_GAMG() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/pc/impls/gamg/gamg.c:803
[0]PETSC ERROR: #6 PCSetUp() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/pc/interface/precon.c:1015
[0]PETSC ERROR: #7 KSPSetUp() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/ksp/interface/itfunc.c:406
[0]PETSC ERROR: #8 KSPSolve_Private() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/ksp/interface/itfunc.c:850
[0]PETSC ERROR: #9 KSPSolve() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/ksp/interface/itfunc.c:1085
[0]PETSC ERROR: #10 PCApply_FieldSplit() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/pc/impls/fieldsplit/fieldsplit.c:1252
[0]PETSC ERROR: #11 PCApply() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/pc/interface/precon.c:444
[0]PETSC ERROR: #12 PCApplyBAorAB() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/pc/interface/precon.c:725
[0]PETSC ERROR: #13 KSP_PCApplyBAorAB() at /home/dc-davi4/rds/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/include/petsc/private/kspimpl.h:393
[0]PETSC ERROR: #14 KSPGMRESCycle() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/ksp/impls/gmres/gmres.c:163
[0]PETSC ERROR: #15 KSPSolve_GMRES() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/ksp/impls/gmres/gmres.c:249
[0]PETSC ERROR: #16 KSPSolve_Private() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/ksp/interface/itfunc.c:912
[0]PETSC ERROR: #17 KSPSolve() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/ksp/ksp/interface/itfunc.c:1085
[0]PETSC ERROR: #18 SNESSolve_NEWTONLS() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/snes/impls/ls/ls.c:225
[0]PETSC ERROR: #19 SNESSolve() at /rds/project/iris_vol2/rds-ukaea-ap001/moose_dev/moose/petsc/src/snes/interface/snes.c:4653
------------------------------------------------------

I had a quick look at Physics Based Precondition (PBP) but the documentation is a bit scarce, https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/preconditioners/PhysicsBasedPreconditioner.html. Would I be better off doing a thermal solve, then pass that thermal solution to a subapp to solve the mechanical part of the problem? Or can someone hint at the right way to set this up as a PBP?

Hello
I added more docs to the PBP in this PR: https://github.com/idaholab/moose/pull/19985/files
It's not merged yet.
@fdkong have you seen this petsc error?
Guillaume

It is a weird error. GAMG is algebraic and it should not care about DM.
@makeclean
Do you mind sharing a simple input file with us on this? I will track it down to reproduce the issue. Regarding the performance, there are many options that can effect performance.   If the other FE code is using PETSc solvers, could you share the results of "-snes_view" if the other FE code uses nonlinear solvers, otherwise "-ksp_view".
With that results, we could setup the same thing for you at the MOSOE side.

The thermal KSP
KSP Object: (nls_solve_) 32 MPI processes
  type: cg
  maximum iterations=10000, initial guess is zero
  tolerances:  relative=1e-08, absolute=1e-50, divergence=10000.
  left preconditioning
  using DEFAULT norm type for convergence test
PC Object: (nls_solve_) 32 MPI processes
  type: hypre
  PC has not been set up so information may be incomplete
    HYPRE BoomerAMG preconditioning
      Cycle type V
      Maximum number of levels 25
      Maximum number of iterations PER hypre call 1
      Convergence tolerance PER hypre call 0.
      Threshold for strong coupling 0.75
      Interpolation truncation factor 0.
      Interpolation: max elements per row 0
      Number of levels of aggressive coarsening 4
      Number of paths for aggressive coarsening 2
      Maximum row sums 0.9
      Sweeps down         1
      Sweeps up           1
      Sweeps on coarse    1
      Relax down          symmetric-SOR/Jacobi
      Relax up            symmetric-SOR/Jacobi
      Relax on coarse     Gaussian-elimination
      Relax weight  (all)      1.
      Outer relax weight (all) 1.
      Using CF-relaxation
      Not using more complex smoothers.
      Measure type        local
      Coarsen type        Falgout
      Interpolation type  classical

The mechanical
KSP Object: (ksp_u_) 32 MPI processes
  type: cg
  maximum iterations=10000, initial guess is zero
  tolerances:  relative=1e-08, absolute=1e-50, divergence=10000.
  left preconditioning
  using DEFAULT norm type for convergence test
PC Object: (ksp_u_) 32 MPI processes
  type: gamg
  PC has not been set up so information may be incomplete
    type is MULTIPLICATIVE, levels=0 cycles=unknown
      Cycles per PCApply=0
      Using externally compute Galerkin coarse grid matrices
      GAMG specific options
        Threshold for dropping small values in graph on each level =  
        Threshold scaling factor for each level not specified = 1.
        AGG specific options
          Symmetric graph false
          Number of levels to square graph 2
          Number smoothing steps 1
        Complexity:    grid = 0.
  linear system matrix = precond matrix:
  Mat Object: 32 MPI processes
    type: mpiaij
    rows=14739, cols=14739, bs=3
    total: nonzeros=602649, allocated nonzeros=602649
    total number of mallocs used during MatSetValues calls=0
      has attached near null space
      using I-node (on process 0) routines: found 158 nodes, limit used is 5

I'll try and make a MWE

sample.zip
Here is the minimum working example
Thanks for example. I will look into it

OK, I looked into this a bit. The issue was that GAMG would use DM to create global vectors when DM is detected since GMAG is built on the top of PCMG. Right now, our DM interface in MOOSE is incomplete. In the current use case, we have to involve DM since FSP is set up via DM.
The short-term solution is to use HYPRE instead of GAMG. I believe you will have a similar performance by replacing GAMG with hypre in FSP.
The long-term solution is to enhance the DM interface in MOOSE #20420. This will take a while since the team is busy ...

Thanks for taking a look into it @fdkong - is could I use PBP instead would that make a difference? Effectively what I'm trying to head towards is a system where I can solve the thermal system with one preconditioner and the (coupled) structural one with another. I could of course do a thermal solve and have my mechanical solve as a subapp, but is there a neater way to do it all in one input?

Effectively what I'm trying to head towards is a system where I can solve the thermal system with one preconditioner and the (coupled) structural one with another.

I meant: you could just replace the GAMG block with HYPRE, and then FSP will work

Do something like this:
[Preconditioning]
  [FSP]
    type = FSP
    topsplit = 'temp_disp'
    [temp_disp]
      splitting = 'temp disp'
      splitting_type = additive
    []
    [temp]
      vars = 'temp'
      petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type -ksp_rtol
                             -pc_hypre_boomeramg_strong_threshold -pc_hypre_boomeramg_coarsen_type 
                             -pc_hypre_boomeramg_interp_type -ksp_type
                             -pc_hypre_boomeramg_agg_nl -pc_hypre_boomeramg_agg_num_paths'
      petsc_options_value = ' hypre      boomeramg   1.0e-8            
                              0.75       HMIS                       
                              ext+i cg
                              4  2'

    []
    [disp]
      vars = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
        petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type -ksp_rtol
                             -pc_hypre_boomeramg_strong_threshold -pc_hypre_boomeramg_coarsen_type 
                             -pc_hypre_boomeramg_interp_type
                             -pc_hypre_boomeramg_agg_nl -pc_hypre_boomeramg_agg_num_paths'
      petsc_options_value = ' hypre      boomeramg   1.0e-8            
                              0.75       HMIS                       
                              ext+i
                              4  2'
    []
  []
[]
Sure, I'll give that a go, but if I wanted to specifically test GAMG then subapp is the way to go? even with a transient problem?

You might have more details about what is your motivation here?  So I understand why you want to do this? If you want to do comparison with other codes,  you might use the same coupling approach as other codes do.

I had a student code up an equivalent physics modules in Fenics/X (https://fenicsproject.org/) and relative to my MOOSE version of the problem, it ran 5x faster. I'm trying to isolate where and why, my initial guess was that it was due to a lot of PC choices I hadn't seen, which was my first go here - to try with the FSP to achieve the same thing. The next nearest thing I can do is a thermal solve, pass that data do the mechanical subapp using the temp as an aux field. I'm trying to achieve similar scaling to his problem, for example, with my full of the problem I can solve 300 timesteps in 12 hours, which I was pretty happy with, but to get that performance I used 360 MPI tasks, 6 tasks per socket which equates to a total of 3360 CPUS reserved (360 being used) across 60 nodes. He was able to do the same with 5 nodes using fully utilised machine, doing all timesteps in 2.5 hours.
This works out to be 23 seconds per fully converged NL cycle in FENICS and over 375 seconds with MOOSE, using my original PC settings. Fenics doesnt update the mesh, this incurs a cost in time. Maybe I should try the initial precondition only. So thats the motivation here, to figure out what the source of this performance gulf is.

Sorry for late reply again.

I'm trying to isolate where and why, my initial guess was that it was due to a lot of PC choices I hadn't seen, which was my first go here - to try with the FSP to achieve the same thing.

FENICS uses PETSc as well. So the first step would be that:
Run the "FENICS" code with the petsc log option "-log_view".
Run the MOOSE code possibly with FSP (HYPRE for both heat conduction and solid mechanics) with the petsc log option "-log_view" and also moose pperfgraph .
With these data, we should be able to have a big picture of where differences come from.
The first step of debugging performance is "profiling". Once you have the results of "-log_view", we will have a better idea.
Put "-log_view" as part of your command line.

@makeclean  My understanding is that your student is solving the two systems separately, without even using fixed point iteration to get a truly converged solution. Please correct me if I'm wrong.
If my understanding is correct, then in order to make an apples-to-apples comparison, you have to use the MultiApp system in MOOSE to setup the two systems individually (without fixed point iteration). I don't think playing with the FSP will give you a completely decoupled system in the sense that you assemble and solve two matrices separately. Again, @makeclean and @fdkong correct me if I'm wrong.
I guess another quick way to check is comparing your MOOSE solution to the FENICS solution.

It is a good point. I am not sure how the physics components are coupled at FENICS.  There could be many things there. @makeclean  Do you have PJFNK at FENICS as well? If it is a pure Newton with an exact matrix, we definitely will see huge performance differences.
It was why I am interested in the results of "-log_view" that will give us a lot of information

node.title: Help with crystal plasticity modeling
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose experts or users,
Happy new year.
Recently, I am working on the crystal plasticity model and thinking about how to write specific code for this model (Wen, Wei, Laurent Capolungo, Anirban Patra, and C. N. Tomé. "A physics-based crystallographic modeling framework for describing the thermal creep behavior of Fe-Cr alloys." Metallurgical and Materials Transactions A 48, no. 5 (2017): 2603-2617.) The PDF is available at https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007/s11661-017-4011-3.pdf.
Two questions:

Should I start from equation [1] or equation [4] when writing code?
If starting from equation [1], I have no idea about how to express the equations [1] and [2] in Moose. In equation [1], how to express ε_ij and n_i, n_j, b_i and b_j for m_ij. Are there any codes developed for reference?



Thank you.

Hi @xchengood,
I would recommend starting with equation 4 from the cited paper. Look at the method calculateSlipRate in the classes CrystalPlasticityTwinningKalidindiUpdate and CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate for examples.
A variation of Equation 1 is implemented in CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase in the method calculateEquivalentSlipIncrement,line 459. In this base class we solve for the plastic velocity gradient, rather than the plastic strain rate as in the Wen et al. paper; see Equation 8 on the ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress documentation page the mathematical details.
Hope this helps,
Stephanie

Dear @xchengood
An example of the implementation we are doing for Orowan's law (your equation [4]) in the CP model in MOOSE is here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/materials/FiniteStrainCrystalPlasticityDislo.C
This is still based on the monolithic CP code,
but if you want to collaborate with us to port it to the UserObject based,
feel free to contact me.
As Stephanie mentioned, equation [1] is already implemented and normally you would not change it,
unless you need to introduce additional mechanisms other than slip.
Best Regards,
Nicolò

Hi @ngrilli and @xchengood
If/when you collaborate to port the monolithic crystal plasticity code, would you refactor the code to the StressUpdate based version (base class here ), and not the User Object version, please? The StressUpdate version has several robustness and speed advantages, which @dewenyushu has shown elsewhere. Additionally, it will be more straightforward to refactor the monothlithic-based code to the StressUpdate version since both versions are solely Material classes.
Thanks!
Stephanie

Dear @sapitts
Thank you very much for the information, I was not aware of that.
I will definitely use the StressUpdate class.
Best Regards,
Nicolò

@sapitts and @ngrilli Thank you very much for your information. It is much helpful for me to achieve this model in Moose. Since I have less experience in the development of Moose, I am still struggling with Moose study. Here, could you help me look at the following equation (10) that I do have no idea how to express it in Moose?

The referenced paper is "Crystal plasticity-based creep model for solution-strengthened nickel-based alloys" (available at Chakraborty P, Jiang W. Crystal plasticity-based creep model for solution-strengthened nickel-based alloys. International Journal of Materials and Structural Integrity. 2019;13(1-3):144-59.)

@xchengood sorry for the late reply, particularly since at this point you may have already solved this issue.
I'd recommend reusing calculateSchmidTensor in the CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase class and passing in the array for the m^a_o vector for both the the plane_normal_vector and direction_vector arguments. Make sure to define a new tensor, too, to hold that dyadic product.
@sapitts. Thank you for your suggestions very much. Appreciate.

node.title: get node ids from a sideset and paired nodes in an Action
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I have a list of sideset names BoundaryName and looking to get the node ids for all the nodes on these sidesets.
also, if there is a way to get the "PairedBoundaryMapping" for that node easily within action or constraint systems.
Ultimately, I am trying to get a list of primary and secondary node ids.
thanks in advance!

Hello
Use the NodalValueSampler and restrict it to those sidesets with the boundary parameter
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/NodalValueSampler.html
The CSV output will have the list of node ids
Guillaume
is there a cleaner way to code it in the action instead?

Oh yes for sure if you are willing to code.
You can loop over all boundaries and select the nodes from there.
Start from  mesh->get_boundary_info(); and build the node list
https://libmesh.github.io/doxygen/classlibMesh_1_1BoundaryInfo.html

It looks like what I need is being done in MeshBase::get_info(), there's SidesetInfo struct that store node_ids
is there an easy way to get to that info? any suggestions would be appreciated.
thanks again!
I believe you're looking for https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/libmesh/classlibMesh_1_1BoundaryInfo.html#a4ab2a9be3fe7eaa1d6f9f5bdc7a9856e

@loganharbour i can see how I can use the suggested function to return each boundary node paired to the sideset id, and then forming the sidesets from that.
but does this support distributed mesh?
I would rather get the info from this, it seems to be more direct, I am just not sure how to get to that info in an Action, and the function doesnt return these info.

It looks like what I need is being done in MeshBase::get_info(), there's SidesetInfo struct that store node_ids
is there an easy way to get to that info? any suggestions would be appreciated.
thanks again!

Oh heh, I'm the one that wrote that in MeshBase.

but does this support distributed mesh?

No, building the side list just builds information pertaining to the local entities (it may also include ghosted entities, but don't quote me on that).  Why do you need to know the global information? In the case of distributed mesh, you should really only want to act on local entities.

Why do you need to know the global information?

I'm trying to get nodal ids to apply a constraint to these nodes. I still will need to find the node pairs for those, but I haven't looked into that yet. ('getPairedBoundaryMapping' seems to be the method used)

You can specify the points manually with this:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/site/source/meshgenerators/ExtraNodesetGenerator.html

unfortunately, the _mesh->dimensionWidth(dim) is not accessible at this section as well, i can do it manually, but is there a way to get it otherwise?
so basically I neither have the total dimension of the cube or the corner node ids at that point of the code.
thanks again

node.title: A 'Migration' is not a registered object？
node.bodyText:
when I run the input.i I receive the error：A 'Migration' is not a registered object
If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically linked library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.
anyone can help me
Code.zip
？

Hello
You forgot to register these objects. See this source file for example, right under the header:
registerMooseObject("MooseApp", Diffusion);

https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/kernels/Diffusion.C
You ll want to register it to your application
Guillaume
thank you so much!!!
